Baku, Nov 22 (EFE).- The United Nations climate summit drafted a proposal Friday, urging wealthy nations contribute $250 billion annually by 2035 to finance climate action in developing countries.

FULL TEXT

Baku, Nov 22 (EFE).- The United Nations climate summit drafted a proposal Friday, urging wealthy nations contribute $250 billion annually by 2035 to finance climate action in developing countries.

The draft agreement marks the first time a concrete figure has been set for such funding at a UN climate conference.

The proposed $250 billion is expected to be sourced from public and private contributions, including multilateral development banks.

The draft also encourages developing nations, including China, to contribute to this collective funding goal under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change guidelines.

The funding would support "ambitious mitigation and adaptation actions" and prioritize transparency in its allocation and application, according to the proposal.

Azerbaijani Presidency's Statement "We gave all groups the opportunity to react to the package of texts we released yesterday morning and we thank them for their constructive engagement," the Azerbaijani COP29 presidency stated.

It urged parties to carefully examine the updated texts, describing them as a balanced foundation for reaching consensus.

Toward a Unified Climate Action Framework The presidency emphasized the importance of collaboration to scale up funding for developing nations, drawing from all available public and private resources.

If adopted, the proposal would represent a significant step forward in addressing climate equity and the financial needs of nations most vulnerable to climate change impacts.

"Further, reflecting the submission of developed country parties, it includes a decision to set a goal in extension of the goal of jointly mobilizing $100 billion per year, with developed country parties taking the lead, to $250 billion by 2035 for developing country parties for climate action."
